propagation in the local zone of the Galaxy as it reveals the spatial distribution of the electrons

Several middle-aged pulsars, such as the Geminga pulsar, are reported to be surrounded
-ray halos with scales larger than 20 pc [1]. These
diﬀusing out from the corresponding pulsar wind nebulae
model of PWN, the original PWNe of the middle-aged pulsars were broken long time ago
[3]. These pulsars are currently traveling in the interstellar medium

(ISM) and driving
bow-shock PWNe with scales
1 pc. This is consistent with the observations of the X-ray
PWN of the Geminga pulsar [5–7]. The TeV
-ray halos are generated mainly through the
inverse Compton scattering (ICS) of the homogeneous cosmic microwave background, so the
morphologies of the halos unambiguously indicate the electron propagation in the ISM.
Cosmic-ray (CR) propagation in the ISM is usually modeled by the diﬀusion process
considering the turbulent nature of the ISM [8]. The diﬀusion approximation is based on
the assumption that the inhomogeneity of the chaotic magnetic ﬁeld has small-scale character
and is negligible in terms of the scale of interest. However, multi-scale inhomogeneities could
exist in the ISM. The ISM is more likely to be a fractal type and the normal diﬀusion can
be generalized to superdiﬀusion [9–12], where the CR propagation is simulated by L´evy
ﬂights instead of the Brownian motion. This model has been applied in the Galactic-scale
propagation of CRs to explain features of the CR energy spectra [9, 13]. In this work, we
test the superdiﬀusion model in a local region of the Galaxy by explaining the morphology
of the Geminga halo. As the diﬀusion packets are diﬀerent for the normal diﬀusion and
-ray morphologies predicted by them could also be distinct.
This paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the superdiﬀusion model
and the solution of the propagation equation. Then we brieﬂy introduce the information of
Geminga in Section III. We ﬁt the
-ray surface brightness proﬁle (SBP) of the Geminga
halo measured by HAWC with diﬀerent propagation models and discuss the ﬁtting results in
Section IV. In Section V we discuss the impact on the interpretation of the positron excess
according to the results of Section IV. Finally, we conclude in Section VI.
will denote both electrons and positrons hereafter.
The pulsars could also be inside their old host SNRs if the SNRs are large enough [4].
After escaping from the source, CRs are continuously scattered by the chaotic magnetic
ﬁeld in the ISM. If the chaotic magnetic ﬁeld is uniformly distributed, the particle trans-
portation can be simulated by the Brownian motion [8]. However, the realistic magnetic
ﬁeld in the ISM may consist of turbulent and relatively regular components, where very long
jumps for CRs are permitted. L´evy ﬂight, which is characterized by the occasionally very
long steps, should be the more proper description in this case [9–12]. For one-dimensional
L´evy ﬂight, the probability density function (PDF) of the individual step length
of the step length is inﬁnite, which is diﬀerent from that of the Brownian motion. The
widening of the diﬀusion packet with time is also faster for L´evy ﬂight (
), so this scenario is named after superdiﬀusion or accelerated

The Geminga pulsar was considered as one of the most competitive candidate sources of
the CR positron excess [25–27]. However, if the slow diﬀusion measured by HAWC pervades
the ISM between Geminga and the solar system, Geminga can hardly contribute to the
positron ﬂux at the Earth as the positrons do not have enough time to reach the Earth
[1]. This problem is alleviated if the slow diﬀusion only happens in the nearby ISM of the
FIG. 4. Left: Positron spectra on the Earth contributed by Geminga with both the normal diﬀusion

for comparison [34]. Right: Positron ﬂuxes from Geminga at 300 GeV as functions of the pulsar
age, corresponding to the models in the left panel.
Geminga pulsar [28–31]. On the other hand, it is possible that the diﬀusion coeﬃcient on
the Galactic disk is generally much smaller than the average value in the Galaxy [32, 33].

observation of HAWC. As the AMS-02 positron spectrum is in the GeV range, it is more
reasonable to use the Fermi-LAT observation of Geminga to constrain the injection spectrum
and diﬀusion coeﬃcient in the same energy range [35]. However, the constraint from Fermi-
LAT is model-dependent and the analysis is beyond the scope of this work.
In this work, we test the superdiﬀusion model in the ISM around the Geminga pulsar
by ﬁtting to the SBP measured by HAWC. This model depicts the particle propagation in
a fractal medium with L´evy ﬂight, which could be more realistic to simulate the intricate
magnetic ﬁeld environment compared with the normal diﬀusion. The L´evy ﬂight superdif-
fusion is described by the fractional Laplacian in the propagation equation with the order of

Due to the nature of the heavy-tailed distribution of the superdiﬀusion model, part of the
positrons come much faster to the Earth and the positron ﬂux from Geminga is much higher
than that predicted by the normal diﬀusion model. Diﬀerent from the conclusion in Ref. [1],
Geminga could have signiﬁcant contribution to the observed high-energy positron spectrum
in the superdiﬀusion scenario even if the small diﬀusion coeﬃcient measured around the
Geminga pulsar is applied in the whole region between Geminga and the Earth.
The test may also provide information for the origin of the ineﬃcient particle propagation
in TeV halos. For example, it is proposed that the slow-diﬀusion zone around the Geminga
pulsar may be interpreted by its crushed relic PWN [30, 31]. Considering the ﬁlamentary
structures in the relic PWN due to Rayleigh-Taylor instabilities [36], this scenario may
be described by the superdiﬀusion model with
then be tested by the method of this work. However, quantitative relations between the
superdiﬀusion model and speciﬁc physical scenarios need to be established in the future.
